body:
Thanks @happynear ! The main reason that we want to go for CMake is for better maintainability. We are open to other options if that serves better.

Your changes to make windows compatibility is valuable. Can you update the PR, or create another PR to only contain the C++ MSVC compatible fix, and please add your name to  https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.md in the PR as well.

Thanks!
After #191  You should be able to run the basic example from any directory
try`std::isnan`?
add using namespace std should work,  @antinucleon  I think we want to remove isnan check
We cannot do `std::isnan` because that code is supposed to run on CUDA as well
k...will remove nan check
OK, I will create another PR and leave the current branch in my repository.

Oh, I try  update_on_kvstore both True and False,  it has no effect, and I try to run mxnet on single gpu,  and inception-bn is 65 sample per sec... compare with two gpu 68 sample per sec(so 34 sample/sec), It seem just like used one gpu, Is there some lock make it slowdown? (I use dmesg can not find any error message, and I test alexnet is no any problem like inception-bn),
This can be solved by cope data.py in the file example/minist

I guess it was due to recent change of default initializer to more conservative one `uniform(0.01)`, was more aggressive before that causing divergence in some deeper archs.

@antinucleon  Can you update the stats?

I see what you mean, there is no such lock that I am aware of. What you observed was interesting.
Could because the synchronization was caped somehow on your machine, mxnet indeed uses cpu heavily because we need to catch up with dynamic dependencies issued in python, maybe you can set the env variables in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/doc/env_var.md related to NTHREADS to 1. and see if that helps.

Thanks for contributing, this is valuable. Please add your name to the  https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.md and I will merge it in. You are more than welcomed to contribute more to mxnet

Fixed in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/196

```

INFO:root:Batch [600]   Speed: 34028.16 samples/sec
INFO:root:Iteration[19] Train-accuracy=1.000000
INFO:root:Iteration[19] Time cost=1.764
INFO:root:Iteration[19] Validation-accuracy=0.990800
```
@tqchen @antinucleon Many thanks! One more question. How can I update my current install of mxnet? Can I just simply `make` and `python setup.py install` again with the newly cloned copy?
You can use `python setup.py develop --user`, then each time you type `make clean; make`, the python pkg will be auto updated
@antinucleon Since I already have mxnet installed, how should I manually update python pkg now with `make clean` before switching to `python setup.py develop --user` next time?

You can simply install again, it should override the original files, as far as I understand

Tianqi

@tqchen Thanks. The original files should have been overridden (^_^). The lenet.py now gives validation accuracy of 99.10%. The mlp.py remains the same as 97.16% - I noticed this file was not modified in @antinucleon 's fix.

BTW, why changing from ReLU to tanh and increasing learning rate from 0.01 to 0.05 help boost the validation accuracy? What I understand is that larger learning rate indicates more aggressive search for a good solution.

After changing ReLU from tanh, mlp.py gives validation accuracy of 97.87%.

Sorry for my unfamiliarity with python resulting in my questions about updating mxnet. I have to be careful since I am working on a server used by many people. Again thanks for your help.
Thanks, looking forward to it!
Glad things works out for you! Thanks for using mxnet.
With respect to learning rate, too large learning rate will results in divergence due to overshooting. So normally we need a moderate learning rate
OK. I have added you to the list and merged the PR. please feel free to contribute further and update your details.
Please check https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/mnist/mlp_numpy.py
I guess the current problem is the label shape should be 1D ndarray, while @II-Matto 's usecase it was shaped as 2D. Maybe we should update the code to make it compatible with both @antinucleon
Yes, actually @happynear  already created on on his fork. We are looking into using CMake solution so the dependency is more maintainable
@caffeTao You may checkout this repo https://github.com/happynear/mxnet before CMake script is written done.
@tqchen Thanks the team for creating mxnet :)

@antinucleon Thanks for you example! I have successfully trained an MLP with my own data.

I noticed that when using numpy.ndarray as input, the validation set is not used. I tried myself but it reported error. To be specific, I have tried two ways. One is

```
model.fit(X=train_data, y=train_label, eval_data=(val_data, val_label))
```

This results in the error of "too many values to unpack" (line 325 in model.py). I checked the model.py and googled for a while. Then I tried the other way.

```
val_set = [(v, c) for v, c in zip(val_data, val_label)]
model.fit(X=train_data, y=train_label, eval_data=val_set)
```

But it results in the error of "invalid index to scalar variable" (line 328 in model.py). It seems to be that the unpacked `label` is a scalar so the index `islice` is not applicable.

So what is the right way to use numpy.ndarray for the `eval_data` argument?

Thanks for contribution! I have added your name to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.md Please feel free to update more information if you like.
We are looking forward to more contributions :)

I try it , nthreads seems no effect,  the main effect on speed are batch_size and mxnet_engine_type, and NaiveEngine is 30 per sec, EngineThread is 50 per sec,  and Default is 68 per sec(all on two 780 gpu)

Thanks. I have no great idea so far. Seems it was due to synchronization cost(maybe PCI bandwith or memory speed). You can try use the most recent version and set

```
kvstore_type = 'device'
```

This will do GPU to GPU copy instead of copy to mainmemory
You will need to assign more to GPU worker threads in this setting.

The error check was caused by original BUG in unary function, due to we never used it

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/ndarray.py#L604

Need to change `(src.handle)` to `(src.handle,)` (add comma), can you update the PR to do that?
Just updated, waiting for the CI to run again.
well, kvstore_type = 'device' is work, and My mechine run 120 sample per sec now, thanks for you help:)
Guess it is caused by your PCI-E bandwith . Good to see it works.

You may also want to set
`MXNET_GPU_WORKER_NTHREADS` to be two, which I observed would help in this setting. Your problem was caused by the PCI-E bandwith, so the device side kvstore works better on your setting.

Glad that things works out for you.  Thanks for using MXNet in the very early stage and help us improve it
Thanks to let me know, My GPU'memory is so poor, and out of memory tor more worker :(

I see, I have created https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/204 so memory allocation algorithm is not strictly tied with GPU threads. You can try 

```
MXNET_EXEC_NUM_TEMP=1
MXNET_GPU_WORKER_NTHREADS=2
```

after the PR is merged in

Thanks, I have one more question, When I build the VGGNet 13layer, on 2 batch_size on 1 gpu used 1500M memory,  but I set 3 batch_size, It raise out of memory(780 has 3000M),  How the memory allocation algorighm work?

The memory allocator will try to re-use the memory as much as possible.  I do not know in particular what happens in your case though. This could due to the memory demand of workspace of CUDNN is nonlinear to batch size(for example, rounded to size of 4)

Year, I try 
MXNET_EXEC_NUM_TEMP=1
MXNET_GPU_WORKER_NTHREADS=2

and It is 5% faster on my machine
Yeah, that is what it can get you

mxnet works fine on my mbp with max os x 10.10. could you please double check your python version? this error is often due to inconsistent of python version (installed mxnet by one python, while run it by another python)
I made a few comments, please also add a simple unittest

Thanks a lot, my python version was 2.7.10 but my g++ version was 4.7. Sorry about that I should check the g++ version before I asked. I change g++ to 4.8 and python to 3.5 and It works now. Really thanks a lot.

The reason is your card didn't provide enough GPU memory, as the default batch size for numpy is 128. In this case, you can run the example in this way:

Change block 2 from:

```
# Load the pre-trained model
prefix = "Inception/Inception_BN"
num_round = 39
model = mx.model.FeedForward.load(prefix, num_round, ctx=mx.gpu())
```

to

```
# Load the pre-trained model
prefix = "Inception/Inception_BN"
num_round = 39
tmp_model = mx.model.FeedForward.load(prefix, num_round, ctx=mx.cpu())
model = mx.model.FeedForward(symbol=tmp_model.symbol, ctx=mx.gpu(), numpy_batch_size=1, arg_params=tmp_model.arg_params, aux_params=tmp_model.aux_params)
```
BTW, I will make a change to original load function to make change batch size easier.

antinucleon,

It works and thanks,

Both method is OK.

As I remembr, `+.Rcpp_MXDArray` is for S3 and S4, `setMethods` is only for S4.
Rcpp_MXNDArray is  S4 object

That is why I said both are OK. We can follow this method.

PS: You won't see warnings below using `+.Rcpp_MXDArray`.


@thirdwing I think we can do a type version check in rcpp side?
I thought the warning will not happen if the setmethods are in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/R/ndarray.R#L4 ? It did not happen on my side
Because init.nd.array is called in onLoad after the library loading

Defining a `init.ndarray.methods` and calling it during startup is not a "common" strategy, but it is OK.

I removed it and saw warnings.

I see, this was really due to our tricky requirement of handling the loading orders.. I thought we can go for the S4 way as it is consider more advanced?

We can think of a more formal way later. But I am afraid we do need a init function solution, due to library loading order problem

well, I see, there is a detail: I run my machine on kvstore_type = 'local' before, It run  68 sam/sec(very slow, use 'device' can run 120 sam/sec), but it first 10 batches run 78 sam/sec, so what ever the gpu speed run, it just slow down...

Could due to our bad col row major conversion code here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/src/ndarray.cc#L13

OK, thanks!

The `train.rec` and `test.rec` is generated by original Alex's python format. We first dump images from the binary file, then [pack them into rec file](https://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/io.html#create-dataset-using-recordio). Note you don't need to set `resize` parameter for im2rec in this case

A sample code I used before to dump images:

```
import os
import sys
import pickle
import csv
import numpy as np
from PIL import Image

if len(sys.argv) < 3:
    print "usage: convert cifar.pkl output_root_folder_path output_list_path"
    exit(-1)

cifar = pickle.load(file(sys.argv[1]))
root = sys.argv[2]
try:
    os.mkdir(root)
except:
    print "%s exists, ignore"

fo = csv.writer(open(sys.argv[3], "w"), lineterminator='\n', delimiter='\t')

data = cifar['data']
label = cifar['fine_labels']
path = cifar['filenames']

sz = data.shape[0]

for i in xrange(sz):
    if i % 1000 == 0:
        print i
    img = data[i]
    p = path[i]
    img = img.reshape((3, 32, 32))
    img = np.swapaxes(img, 0, 2)
    img = np.swapaxes(img, 0, 1)
    im = Image.fromarray(img)
    im.save(root + p)
    row = [i, label[i], p]
    fo.writerow(row)
```
link to binary version of data http://www.cs.toronto.edu/~kriz/cifar-100-binary.tar.gz binary version of data, also can you share your trained model for cifar100 like cafe.

Should not be. What is your system and is your GPU occupied by other task? While running program, you can type `nvidia-smi` to see the GPU-Util value
Also, have you tested other example? As mlp.py is a tiny example, it won't fully use GPU. Please check CIFAR-10 example and report the speed.
My system is Win 8. I think my GPU is not occupied by other task. I just compiled it and tested it with mlp. I'll test other examples and give some feedback later.

Also just a side note for OSX compilation: if we add `-I/System/Library/Frameworks/Accelerate.framework/Versions/Current/Frameworks/vecLib.framework/Versions/Current/Headers/` to `ADD_CFLAGS` then there is no need to install third-party BLAS.
